resources.string: Brazil
Marijuana is illegal for recreational use.\nMedical use is heavily regulated.\nScientific use is heavily regulated.
Possession of any amount of marijuana for personal use is illegal and subject to legal penalties.\nThe law does not distinguish the amount for personal use, any possession can lead to charges.

Consumption of marijuana in any form is illegal when it comes to recreational use.\nMedical use is permitted within the confines of a prescription and should be consumed as directed by a healthcare provider.

Medical marijuana was legalized in 2006 under law 11.343 Lei das Drogas but is strictly controlled. 
It is only available to patients with certain qualifying conditions and requires a prescription. 
The usual path is for Brazilians to obtain a Habeas Corpus and be allowed to plant. 
The range of products available is limited and expensive.
The cultivation of marijuana plants for personal or recreational use is illegal.\nCultivation for medical purposes is allowed under strict government licenses and for pharmaceutical purposes.

The sale and distribution of marijuana are illegal and associated with severe penalties.\nMedical marijuana can be obtained from licensed pharmacies with a valid prescription from a qualified medical professional.\nMedical marijuana can be obtained by cultivating it yourself if you have a valid license.

Law Enforcement in Brazil is pretty serious and violent.\n"Minorities" such as black or poor people are more persecuted and thus are at a greater risk of law enforcement situations.\nPenalties for marijuana possession, sale, or cultivation can include fines, mandatory treatment programs, and imprisonment.

Canada

Cannabis is legal in Canada for both recreational and medical purposes.\nProvincial and territorial regulations complement the federal Cannabis Act, with some variations in rules such as the legal age and personal cultivation.
Adults are allowed to carry and share up to 30 grams of legal cannabis in public.\nCannabis must be purchased from licensed stores or provincial/territorial online platforms.

Cannabis can be consumed in private residences or in designated public spaces where tobacco smoking is permitted, but this varies by province/territory.\nSome provinces and territories have specific restrictions on where cannabis can be consumed, such as in vehicles or parks.

Medical use of cannabis was legalized in Canada in 2001.\nPatients with a prescription from a healthcare provider can purchase medical cannabis from licensed producers, grow their own, or designate someone to grow it for them.
Adults are allowed to grow up to four cannabis plants per household for personal use, but this is subject to provincial or territorial restrictions.\nNot all provinces allow home cultivation.
Cannabis can be purchased from retailers licensed by the provinces and territories.\nThe minimum age for purchase and use varies by province and territory, generally ranging between 18 and 21 years.

Enforcement of cannabis-related laws is a shared responsibility between federal, provincial, and municipal governments.\nPenalties for illegal possession, distribution, or cultivation vary depending on the severity of the offense.

Slovakia
Marijuana is illegal for recreational use.
Possession of any amount of marijuana for personal use is illegal and subject to legal penalties.\nThe law does not distinguish the amount for personal use, any possession can lead to charges.

Consumption of marijuana in any form is illegal when it comes to recreational use.\nMedical use is permitted within the confines of a prescription and should be consumed as directed by a healthcare provider.

Medical marijuana was legalized in 2011 but is strictly controlled.\nIt is only available to patients with certain qualifying conditions and requires a prescription.\nThe range of products available is limited, and Slovakia has strict regulations on the types of products that can be prescribed.
The cultivation of marijuana plants for personal or recreational use is illegal.\nCultivation for medical purposes is allowed under strict government licenses and for pharmaceutical purposes.

The sale and distribution of marijuana are illegal and associated with severe penalties.\nMedical marijuana can only be obtained from licensed pharmacies with a valid prescription from a qualified medical professional.

Slovak law enforcement agencies take drug offenses seriously, and this includes offenses involving marijuana.\nPenalties for marijuana possession, sale, or cultivation can include fines, mandatory treatment programs, and imprisonment.
